clinical_summary: On 2025-07-22 laboratory testing revealed markedly elevated conjugated bilirubin (7.79 mg/dL), mildly increased unconjugated bilirubin (1.63 mg/dL), elevated AST (162 U/L) and ALT (86 U/L), markedly increased alkaline phosphatase (396 U/L) and gamma‑glutamyl transferase (263 U/L), with low-normal albumin (3.7 g/dL) and normal total protein, globulin, and A/G ratio, indicating a cholestatic pattern of liver injury.

differential_diagnoses.name: Obstructive cholestasis (e.g., biliary obstruction or gallstone disease)
differential_diagnoses.justification: Conjugated bilirubin markedly elevated with high alkaline phosphatase and GGT suggests extra‑hepatic biliary obstruction.

differential_diagnoses.name: Intrahepatic cholestasis (e.g., drug‑induced or autoimmune)
differential_diagnoses.justification: Elevated conjugated bilirubin together with high ALP and GGT can occur in intrahepatic cholestasis without clear obstruction.

differential_diagnoses.name: Acute viral or inflammatory hepatitis
differential_diagnoses.justification: AST and ALT are elevated, though less than ALP, indicating hepatocellular injury that may coexist with cholestasis.

differential_diagnoses.name: Primary biliary cholangitis or primary sclerosing cholangitis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Cholestatic laboratory profile (high conjugated bilirubin, ALP, GGT) is characteristic of chronic cholestatic liver diseases.

differential_diagnoses.name: Hemolysis
differential_diagnoses.justification: Mildly elevated unconjugated bilirubin could reflect hemolysis, but lack of anemia data makes this less likely.
